final_answer.precision_note: The limiting given concentration is 0.150 (3 s.f.), so report to 3 s.f.

method: Calculate moles of NaOH used: n(NaOH) = cV with V in dm3. Convert 23.40 cm3 to 0.02340 dm3, so n(NaOH) = 0.150 × 0.02340 = 0.00351 mol. From H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O, 2 mol NaOH neutralize 1 mol H2SO4, so n(H2SO4) = 0.00351/2 = 0.001755 mol. The acid volume is 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3, therefore c(H2SO4) = n/V = 0.001755/0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
checks: Because 2 mol NaOH react per 1 mol acid, the acid concentration should be about half the NaOH concentration after accounting for similar volumes; 0.0702 is reasonable.
